title: Distinct Subset Products
content: A set has distinct subset products if every subset yields a unique product. The empty subset gives 1, singletons give themselves, and all larger subsets must also be distinguishable by their products.

title: The Function g(n)
content: g(n) is the maximum size of a subset of {1,...,n} with distinct subset products. The problem asks for tight asymptotic bounds on this function.

title: Prime Counting Function
content: π(n) counts primes up to n. The prime number theorem gives π(n) ~ n/log n, but the exact relationship to g(n) involves careful analysis.

title: Erdős's Upper Bound
content: Erdős (1966) proved g(n) ≤ π(n) + O(n^{1/2}/log n). This shows g(n) is dominated by the prime count plus a lower-order term.

title: The Main Conjecture
content: Erdős asked whether g(n) ≤ π(n) + π(√n) + o(n^{1/2}/log n). This would show the primes-plus-prime-squares construction is essentially optimal.

title: Raghavan's Upper Bound
content: Raghavan (2025) proved g(n) ≤ π(n) + π(√n) + O(n^{5/12+o(1)}). The error term n^{5/12} is much smaller than the conjectured o(n^{1/2}/log n).

title: Raghavan's Lower Bound
content: Raghavan also showed g(n) ≥ π(n) + π(√n) + π(∛n)/3 - O(1). This proves optimal sets include contributions from primes, their squares, AND some cubes.

title: Conjecture Confirmed
content: The main theorem: Erdős's conjecture is TRUE. For large n, Raghavan's upper bound implies the conjectured bound since n^{5/12} = o(n^{1/2}/log n).

title: Primes Have Distinct Products
content: The primes ≤ n automatically have distinct subset products by the fundamental theorem of arithmetic—different prime sets give different products.

title: Adding Prime Squares
content: Adding squares of small primes maintains distinct products. If p² is in the set, it contributes a factor of 2 to the exponent of p, distinguishable from using p once or not at all.

title: Structure of Optimal Sets
content: Key structural result: optimal sets decompose into primes P, prime squares P², and a small remainder R. The remainder has size at most π(∛n)/2.

title: Multiplicative Sidon Set
content: A multiplicative Sidon set has no non-trivial product relations: ab = cd implies {a,b} = {c,d}. This is stronger than having distinct subset products.

title: Sidon Implies Distinct Products
content: Multiplicative Sidon sets automatically have distinct subset products, but the converse fails—distinct products is a weaker condition.

title: Example: {2, 3, 5}
content: The set {2, 3, 5} has distinct subset products: 1, 2, 3, 5, 6, 10, 15, 30 are all different. This illustrates the primes-only construction.

title: Counterexample: {2, 3, 6}
content: The set {2, 3, 6} does NOT have distinct products: {6} and {2, 3} both give product 6. Including composite numbers creates collisions.
